title: Teen defies the odds to walk out of hospital six months after breaking his neck
text:
A teenager has walked out of hospital just six months on from breaking his neck, after he unknowingly struck a sandbank while diving into water at Mullaloo Beach .

After learning to walk again, Matthew Haylett now has his sights set on playing football once again .

But today, it was an emotional farewell to those who helped him get back on his feet as the 18-year-old left Fiona Stanley Hospital after five months.

READ MORE: Former Italian restaurant owner jailed

Teenager Matthew Haylett has walked out of hospital just six months on from breaking his neck, after he unknowingly struck a sandbank while diving into water at Mullaloo beach. (9News)

"It's really overwhelming the fact he survived it, let alone he's walking again, it's just unreal - and just look at that love," mother Megan Larson told 9News.

The teenager broke his neck diving into water at Mullaloo beach in March and hitting a sandbank.

His mate saved his life by pulling him onto shore.

Haylett spent a month at Royal Perth Hospital after spinal surgery and was told he may never walk again after being paralysed from the neck down.

Haylett spent a month at Royal Perth Hospital after spinal surgery and was told he may never walk again after being paralysed from the neck down. (9News)

"That was strange," the 18-year-old recalled.

"First couple of days it's just like your head's floating then slowly you get some feeling back and I could move my arm.

"It took a couple weeks to get a twitch in my leg."

He was eventually transferred to Fiona Stanley Hospital for rehabilitation, which included a dozen gym sessions per week.

His recovery progressed quickly, leaving staff stunned.

"He came in with a C5-6 injury, so it's quite high, he was in a collar and not doing much in bed, so no-one expected him to be as great as he is today," clinical nurse Monique Carbone told 9News.

Six weeks after the accident, Haylett had an inspirational visit from Thomas Davison, who had suffered the same fate (9News)

Six weeks after the accident, Haylett had an inspirational visit from Thomas Davison, who had suffered the same fate after plunging into a sandbank at Mandurah Town Beach in 2023.

Two years on from his own accident, Davison gave Haylett some hope with the 17-year-old defying the odds and learning to drive.

"I had one goal for myself and that was just to get out of that wheelchair. I've succeeded [with] that now," Davison told 9News earlier this year.

Even though Haylett's now been discharged, he still has a lot of recovery ahead of him.

He'll complete eight weeks of rehabilitation at home as well as regular appointments at Fiona Stanley Hospital.

The Western Power apprentice now looking forward to getting back to work, driving his car and hopefully playing sport. (9News)

The Western Power apprentice is looking forward to getting back to work, driving his car and hopefully playing sport.

His advice for those recovering from serious injuries is to really put in the effort.

"You get what you put into it," he said.

"All the physio and staff are here to help, just try and do as much as you can. Everyone's different so you don't know how it's going to end up but just make the best of it."

title: What will and won't be open on the public holiday
text:
Millions of Australians will have some time off this weekend as they celebrate one of two public holidays.

For Aussies in South Australia, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, it will be their Labour Day.

Queensland residents will have a public holiday on the same day to commemorate the King's Birthday.

So what will be the trading hours for Australia's biggest retailers this long weekend?

Here's a quick state-by-state guide. ﻿

Coles

Stores across NSW, ACT and QLD will be open as normal.

﻿In SA, all stores will be closed except for﻿ Port Lincoln, Port Pirie, Berri, Port Augusta, Mount Barker, Adelaide Rundle Place, Whyalla, Murray Bridge Green, Mount Gambier and Victor Harbor.

Full trading hours can be found on their website .

Aldi

Store hours will vary for different stores and states.

Full trading hours for each store can be found on their website﻿

READ MORE: When October long weekend double demerits apply for motorists

Aldi recommends that customers check their local stores trading hours on their website (Nine)

Woolworths

All stores except for some in South Australia and the Northern Territory will be open.

﻿Full trading hours can be found on their website .

Liquorland

Stores in states celebrating the public holidays will trade with reduced trading hours.﻿

In Queensland,﻿ some stores will be closed for the public holiday.

Full trading hours can be found on their website .

READ MORE: How to maximise public holidays and make the most of your annual leave in 2025

Some stores in Queensland will be closed for the public holiday. (Jon W / Event Photos Australia)

Dan Murphy's and BWS

﻿Dan Murphy's stores nationwide will mostly open from 10am to 7pm.

BWS stores will mostly open from 9am and close between 7pm and 8pm.

Full trading hours can be found on their website﻿ .

Bunnings﻿

All Bunnings stores will be open on the October long weekend.

Most stores in states where there is a public holiday will be open from 7am to 7pm.﻿

﻿Shoppers are advised to use the Bunnings website or app to check their local store's trading hours, as opening times will vary.

Bunnings stores statewide will remain open on the public holidays. (Supplied)

title: Heartbroken mum calls for vaccines to be funded after teen's sudden death
text:
A devastated mother is calling for the meningococcal B vaccine to be made available to all children and teenagers, after her 16-year-old son died suddenly last week.

Melbourne mum Norliah Syer-Peterson said her son Levi fell ill with what appeared to be gastro-like symptoms on Tuesday, September 23, before his condition deteriorated rapidly.

Levi, who was a Year 10 student at St Francis Xavier College in Beaconsfield, appeared perfectly happy and healthy in the morning, his mother told 9news.com.au.

READ MORE: Shots fired at suburban home while occupants slept

Levi had just turned 16 and gotten his learner driver's licence. (Supplied: Norliah Syer-Peterson)

"I had dropped him off to do some work with my brother, who is a removalist," Syer-Peterson said.

"We were joking around, and we were talking about how we were going to have a mum and son fun day during the holidays."

However, when Levi came home that afternoon, he complained of having a stiff neck.

"He was in the truck, and he said he fell asleep, and that's not unusual to get a stiff neck if you're lying weirdly in a truck," Syer-Peterson said.

Levi's mother said she gave him some water and ran him a bath.

"He refused to eat, and he eats like 10,000 meals a day, so that was strange," she added.

Levi told his mother that he felt nauseous, so she gave him a bucket and he went to bed.

Hours later, the family was woken at around 1.30am by a loud banging sound.

Levi was vomiting in the bathroom.

"He was delirious, and the deliriousness was concerning," Syer-Peterson said

"He was just mumbling stuff and talking about a person he doesn't even know."

Norliah Syer-Peterson, pictured with her son Levi. (Supplied: Norliah Syer-Peterson)

Now alarmed, Syer-Peterson called triple zero and, when paramedics arrived, they immediately administered antibiotics.

"They said, 'It looks like he's got an infection.' But then he started complaining about having a sore leg, and they were trying to get fluids into him," his mother said, adding Levi had a temperature of 41 degrees.

"He said, 'Am I going to die', and we all said, 'No, no, no.'"

The paramedics rushed him to the intensive care unit at Monash Children's Hospital.

"He went straight into the ICU unit. There were probably 40 professionals in there working on him, doctors, nurses, people monitoring him.

"It was full on, like something out of a nightmare movie."

Levi developed purple spots all over his skin, and then his heart stopped.

The much-loved teen died at around 7.30am last Wednesday, less than 24 hours after he first fell ill.

Syer-Peterson said her son's sudden death had left the family reeling.

"He was just the most gentle, kind, loving, sweet, beautiful boy," she said of her son.

"He used to pray a lot for people. He loved basketball, and he played netball with one of his girlfriends."

Levi, pictured with his mother Norliah Syer-Peterson and older brother Zac. (Supplied: Norliah Syer-Peterson)

Levi had just gotten his learner driver's licence and had been busy making plans for the year ahead, his mother said.

"He had braces on that he was going to get off later this year. He was doing his deb next year, in March," she said.

Tests have confirmed Levi died of sepsis caused by meningococcal B bacteria.

Like most Year 10 students in Victoria, Levi received a free meningococcal vaccine at school, which covers strains A, C, W and Y.

However, meningococcal B requires a separate vaccine, which is only included in the National Immunisation Program for at-risk groups, such as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander infants.

After lobbying by medical experts and advocates, some Australian states - Queensland, South Australia and the Northern Territory - have chosen to fund their own meningococcal B vaccination programs to make the vaccines free for all children and teens.

However, Victoria, NSW, the ACT and Tasmania are yet to do so.

Syer-Peterson said she was now making it her mission to lobby for meningococcal B vaccines to be made available free of charge.

"I would say that it is ridiculous that this is not funded. People, normal Australians, can't afford to pay for it," she said, adding that it never even occurred to her to get Levi the extra vaccination.

The Australian Technical Group on Immunisation (ATAGI), which advises the health minister on the National Immunisation Program, recommended the meningococcal B vaccine be given to infants, young children and adolescents in 2014.

A Department of Health spokesperson told 9news.com.au the inclusion of any vaccine on the federal program was contingent on a positive recommendation from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), based on an assessment of clinical and cost-effectiveness.

"To date, the PBAC has not received an application from pharmaceutical companies seeking expanded eligibility for meningococcal B vaccine," the spokesperson said.

There have been 13 cases of meningococcal B in Victoria so far this year.

A spokesperson for Victoria's Health Department said: "The Chief Health Officer monitors the prevalence of meningococcal cases in Victoria, which informs their independent health advice on vaccination settings.

title: Names for the next tropical cyclones over Australia are a mixed bunch
text:
A punk rock icon and a fermented Japanese rice have helped inspire the names of the next tropical cyclones in Australia﻿.

T﻿he Bureau of Meteorology has released the new names ahead of next month's start of the storm season, which runs until late April, reports weather forecasting site Weatherzone .

The next six months has the potential for nine to 11 tropical cyclones, which is about average for Australia.

Cyclone Errol impacted Western Australia earlier this year.. (Weatherzone)

A handful of those can be expected to reach severe level, categorised by meteorologists as level three or stronger.﻿

The first new tropical cyclone will be known as Fina, while the remainder include Iggy, synonymous with legendary rocker Iggy Pop, and Koji, a rice grain used to make Miso.

They run in alphabetical order and alternate between male and female. The 11 new names are: Fina, Grant, Hayley, Iggy, Jenna, Koji, Launa, Mitchell, Narelle, Oran and Peta.

Australia's tropical cyclones have been named by the bureau since the mid 1960s.

Initially, the cyclones were only given female names – with the first official names being Audrey and Bessie in 1964.

During the past 62 years of wild weather, some of the most destructive cyclones in Australian history have been named Tracy, Larry, Olivia, Debbie and Alfred.﻿

Earlier this year, the bureau decided to change the name of a major tropical cyclone off northern Queensland from Anthony to Alfred.

The move was made to avoid confusion with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese ahead of May's federal election.

title: US climbing star dies in fall from Yosemite's El Capitan
text:
A popular Alaskan climber has fallen to his death from Yosemite National Park's El Capitan, marking the third death in the US park this summer.

Balin Miller, 23, died in a climbing accident on Wednesday, his mother Jeanine Girard-Moorman confirmed.

“He’s been climbing since he was a young boy,” she said.

Balin Miller sits atop Mount Hunter on May 14, 2025 after summiting via the French Connection route solo. (Balin Miller)

“His heart and soul was truly to just climb.

“He loved to climb and it was never about money and fame.”

The death comes on the first day of the federal government shutdown, which left national parks “generally” open, with limited operations and closed visitors centers, according to the National Park Service.

The park service did not respond to an email requesting comment, and it's unclear what staff remains at Yosemite during the shutdown.

El Capitan is one of the most striking features of Yosemite National Park, an enormous sheer granite rock face of approximately 915 metres that entices big-wall rock climbers from all over the world.

Alex Honnold completed the first free solo climb of El Capitan in 2017 for the documentary Free Solo .

The famed El Capitan rock face. (Adobe Stock)

Many posted tributes to Miller on social media, saying they had watched him climb on a TikTok livestream for two days before his death and referring him to “orange tent guy" because of his distinctive camp setup.

Earlier this year, an 18-year-old from Texas died in the park while free-soloing, or climbing without a rope, on a different formation. In August, a 29-year-old woman died after being struck in the head by a large tree branch while hiking.

While it's still unclear exactly what happened, his older brother, Dylan Miller, said Balin was lead rope soloing — a way to climb alone while still protected by a rope — on a 730-metre route named Sea of Dreams.

He had already finished the climb and was hauling up his last bit of gear when he likely rappelled off the end of his rope, Dylan said.

Miller was an accomplished alpinist who had already gained international attention for claiming the first solo ascent of Mount McKinley's Slovak Direct, a technically difficult route that took him 56 hours to complete, he posted on his Instagram in June.

He grew up climbing in Alaska with his brother and their father, who was also a climber.

While Dylan took a little more time to fall in love with the sport, it stuck with his younger sibling instantly.

“He said he felt most alive when he was climbing,” Dylan Miller said.

“I’m his bigger brother but he was my mentor.”

This year, Balin Miller had also spent weeks solo climbing in Patagonia and the Canadian Rockies, ticking off a notoriously difficult ice climb called Reality Bath, which had been unrepeated for 37 years, according to Climbing magazine.

"He’s had probably one of the most impressive last six months of climbing of anyone that I can think of,” Clint Helander, an Alaska alpinist, told the Anchorage Daily News .

But this most recent trip to Yosemite wasn't supposed to be hard climbing.

Miller had just arrived two weeks early to climb and enjoy the park's beauty and solitude before the rest of his family, who planned to meet up there.

More than just a climber, he loved animals and was fun, kind and full of life, his mother said.

He often climbed with a stripe of glitter freckles across his cheekbones, describing it in a Climbing magazine interview like “a warrior putting makeup on before going into battle”.

title: Excavators find $1.5 million in gold coins from Spanish shipwreck
text:
Hidden beneath the turquoise waters off a stretch of Florida known as the “Treasure Coast,” a team of divers from a shipwreck salvage company have uncovered exactly that — a load of long-lost Spanish treasure they estimate is worth US$1 million (A$1.5 million).

More than 1,000 silver and gold coins thought to be minted in the Spanish colonies of Bolivia, Mexico and Peru were uncovered this summer off Florida's Atlantic coast, 1715 Fleet – Queens Jewels LLC announced this week.

It's not the first time the site has yielded a trove of, well, treasure.

In this undated photo provided by shipwreck salvage company 1715 Fleet- Queens Jewels, LLC, diver Levin Shavers shows coins uncovered from a Spanish shipwreck off the Atlantic coast of Florida. (LLC via AP)

Centuries ago, a fleet of Spanish ships laden with gold, silver and jewels taken from the New World was sailing back to Spain when a hurricane wrecked the flotilla on July 31, 1715, spilling the treasures into the sea, according to the 1715 Fleet Society.

Over the years, millions of dollars in gold coins from the 1715 Fleet have been found by salvagers and treasure hunters in a coastal area stretching from Melbourne to Fort Pierce.

Dates and mint marks are still visible on some of the recently recovered coins, the salvage company said, a benefit for historians and collectors hoping to glean more from the lost treasure.

“This discovery is not only about the treasure itself, but the stories it tells,” Sal Guttuso, director of operations for the salvage company said in a statement.

“Each coin is a piece of history, a tangible link to the people who lived, worked, and sailed during the Golden Age of the Spanish Empire. Finding 1,000 of them in a single recovery is both rare and extraordinary.”

Guttuso's team employs dive crews and a fleet of boats and uses underwater metal detection-devices, plus hand-fanning of sand or sand suction to comb the sea floor, according to a public notice for a federal permit application the company filed.

Last year, Florida officials announced they had recovered dozens of gold coins stolen by salvagers from the wreck. The suspect was identified as a family member of the team contracted by 1715 Fleet – Queens Jewels LLC to work the site.

Divers find 100 bottles of 'royal' champagne on shipwreck View Gallery

Under Florida law, any “treasure trove” or other historic artifacts “abandoned” on state-owned lands or in state waters belong to the state, though excavators can be permitted to carry out “recovery services.”

The law requires that roughly 20 percent of the recovered archaeological materials be retained by the state for research collections or public display.

Guttuso told The Associated Press his team develops a detailed inventory of all the artifacts collected each season to be reviewed by the state.

Florida officials select up to 20 percent of the items to keep for the public, in a negotiation process that is ultimately approved by a federal court. Remaining artifacts are split equally among the salvage company's owners and its subcontractors, Guttuso said.

"We want to do it right," Guttuso said.

“And it benefits the people of Florida. They end up in the museums,” he said of the treasures.

title: Could thunderstorms hold the key to stronger crops?
text:
A Cairns biotech startup is combining traditional Indigenous knowledge of "rainmaking" and modern science to optimise plant and fungi growth.

The company Rainstick is using electrical fields to treat seeds to improve germination and productivity.

Its technique is based on a tradition of the Maiawali people of central west Queensland, who used a chuggera or a lightning stick to direct thunderstorm activity.

Riverine Plains is trialling Rainstick’s seed treatment on canola crops in regional Victoria. (ABC Landline)

Darryl Lyons is co-founder and "chief rainmaker".

"Chief rainmaker sounds like a really cool title," he said.

" But really, it's about figuring out how we can scale this technology globally to make a difference in agriculture. "

His business partner Mic Black is the "chief thunderstorm creator".

"We take seeds and we apply an electric field similar to what happens during a thunderstorm … those seeds get shipped out to the producer for them to grow," he said.

The process is designed to be seamless for farmers, as it does not require changes to existing planting and growing processes.

Testing the tech on canola crops

Rainstick has been experimenting with small-scale indoor crops but is also collaborating with Riverine Plains, a farming systems group with more than 450 members conducting trials on broadacre crops such as canola.

Chief executive Pip Grant said low crop establishment rates were a significant problem for Australian farmers.

The CSIRO and the Grains Research and Development Corporation have found it costs the canola industry more than $100 million a year.

Pip Grant says low canola establishment rates are a costly issue for farmers. (ABC Landline)

If the seed treatment is successful, it could boost productivity and cut those costs.

"We're really working with the Rainstick team on the broadacre," Ms Grant said.

" How do we actually translate this technology from mushrooms, bok choy, our indoor sort of crops, to what that looks like once we bring it out into broadacre crops? "

The initial visual assessments of the canola trials are promising.

"It has actually been quite wild to see the difference in some of the treated … canola plants versus the control," Ms Grant said.

The next step is to harvest the plots and analyse the data to confirm any potential yield and economic benefits.

The science behind the storm

The Rainstick team is also working with scientists from James Cook University (JCU) and the University of Queensland to fine-tune their seed treatment technology.

"We work with a couple of basic elements to our formula," Mr Black said.

"We have our frequency, our waveform and the duration of that treatment.

"You can't [apply] brute force [to] something like this."

JCU researcher Joost Nelis is assisting with the scientific evaluation of the technology's effect on plants.

Joost Nelis studies how bioelectrical treatments affect plant growth. (ABC Landline)

Dr Nelis is measuring changes in key molecules within the plants to understand how the treatment influences their biological processes.

He said his research, which focused on how different metabolic pathways were activated in the process, had already observed some differences.

"One of the things we observed so far is that there's really an increase in leaf mass after the treatment," he said.

Mr Black made it clear the technology was not genetic modification, nor a chemical treatment.

Mic Black with seedlings in the company’s indoor crop trials. (ABC Landline)

Instead, the bio-electrical signals influence how genes react without altering the plant's DNA.

The goal is to give seedlings a stronger, more vigorous start that can potentially last throughout the entire growth cycle.

A vision for a sustainable future

The potential applications of Rainstick's technology extend beyond traditional farming.

Mr Lyons is passionate about its use in reforestation projects.

"We've got to reforest mine [sites], we've got to reforest areas globally to help with climate variation," he said.

Early trial results show visible differences between treated and untreated canola plants. (ABC Landline)

The team is trailing the technology on native species such as grevilleas and Darwin stringybarks, both of which have poor establishment rates.

For Mr Lyons, a Maiawali man, this work is not just a business, it is a personal journey.

"Unfortunately, my great-grandmother was the only survivor from the Maiawali people," he said.

"I've kind of been lucky over the last 15 years to go back out in the country and connect to that heritage."

He believes that traditional knowledge could have a global impact by providing new scientific solutions.

Rainstick plans to continue in-field trials in collaboration with farmers and scientists.

Ms Grant said they were still in the early stages, but the partnership was crucial to determine the price points for a farm to receive a return on their investment in the technology.

Watch ABC TV's Landline at 12:30pm AEST on Sunday or stream anytime on ABC iview.

title: Vendors concerned by low crowds, price crunch at Perth Royal Show
text:
Perth Royal Show vendors say they are considering not returning next year, as the cost of operating ratchets up while business falls.

Official attendance figures for this year's show are yet to be released, but many vendors have said this year has felt much quieter than previous shows.

Game vendor Kirsty said there was no longer the deluge of customers at stalls she was used to.

Crowds at the show are said to be thinner than in previous years. (ABC News: Kenith Png)

"We're having big breaks in between customers, which normally we'd have like big flows of customers, so it has definitely changed this year," she said.

" It is worse, definitely worse. "

Kirsty said she believed the solution was to lower the prices of activities and merchandise at the show.

"[We need to] drop prices. But, the cost of living, we can't. There's nothing we can do unless the state government does something about it," she said.

Entry to the Royal Show for anyone over 16 was $50 this year.

Last year, after government funding halved the admission price, it was just $22 for adults and children were free.

Some vendors have said the crowds have felt smaller at this year's show. (ABC News: Cason Ho )

Some vendors and attendees attributed what seemed like smaller crowds this year to the higher entry prices.

"Last year we were struggling to line up for the show rides, and today hasn't been too bad," mother Rhiannon said.

Rhiannon says the kids were loving the Perth Royal Show. (ABC News: Cason Ho )

"It's an expensive day out but the kids are loving it, so that's the main thing."

Double blow

Merchandise vendor Roberto Vago said stall operators were being hit with a double whammy, managing lower foot-traffic while also paying more to set up shop.

"I've been doing this for nearly 15 years now — I can definitely say that price went double than what we used to pay," Mr Vago said.

He said the price hike for his store's lot, from last year, is the biggest he's ever experienced.

Roberto Vago says he paid much morre for his stall this year. (ABC News: Cason Ho )

"It was $4000 [last year], and this year we pay more than $10,000, and that's pretty much for the same location," he said.

Mr Vago said many vendors had to put up prices on food and merchandise to survive.

The ABC understands a group of vendors are putting together a petition to the Royal Agricultural Society of WA [RASWA] to lobby for better conditions and costs.

The RASWA said it would have a full tally of attendance figures after the Royal Show's last day on Saturday, and would reveal them early next week.

It said it had seen a "steady increase in after-5pm entries each day", and had received "positive feedback from vendors and operators".

After the government halved the price of attending the show for adults last year, this year's return to full price has been felt keenly. (ABC News: Cason Ho )

"This year's Perth Royal Show has focused strongly on enhancing the patron experience, guided by feedback that 87 per cent of visitors believe agriculture should remain at the heart of the show," a spokesperson said.

"Patrons also told us they wanted more agricultural education and a greater variety of food, and the response has been overwhelmingly positive."

title: Community invited to join 'magnificent' pop-up rock supergroup
text:
They may not be the headline act at this year's Wanderer Festival, but without a doubt, they are the most ambitious.

The Big Lost Band is a pop-up, all-ages rock'n'roll supergroup with more than 130 members at last count.

This year, the band has 12 drum kits, 40 guitars and basses, a choir and a horn and strings section.

They have just four, two-hour rehearsals to prepare for two shows at the festival on the New South Wales far south coast that are "too joyous and magnificent to ignore," according to festival artistic director and self-described band wrangler, Ian Pidd.

There are 25 musicians in this year's brass and string section. (ABC South East NSW: Adriane Reardon)

The band particularly encourages people who have lost touch with their instruments or have just discovered their instruments.

"The reason it works is that a whole lot of people do a whole lot of work, and then they just hang on by their fingernails and get it done," he said.

" It's a combination of fear and trust and joy. "

Four rehearsals before showtime

At the start of each rehearsal, the band breaks into sections — drums led by Chris Jones, guitars led by Dean Gray, and brass, strings and keyboards led by Nick and Sarah Keeling — while Ian Pidd leads the choir.

Chris Jones leads the drum section. (ABC South East NSW: Adriane Reardon)

With the woodwind and brass instruments all set to different key signatures to match the guitars and choir, many of the budding musicians are playing notes they've never played before.

Robbie O'Neill is realising a dream she has had since she was a teenager to play saxophone.

She started having lessons four months before she joined the Big Lost Band.

"I'd only learnt maybe eight notes," she said.

"But the two saxophonists who can play are very helpful."

Robbie O'Neill is realising a dream she has had since she was a teenager to learn saxophone. (ABC South East NSW: Adriane Reardon)

Robbie's not sure if she'll be show-ready in four rehearsals, but she has a fallback plan just in case.

"If I can't play, I just won't blow", she laughs.

This year, the band's set list includes Peter Gabriel's Sledgehammer and Radiohead's Creep.

Nick Keeling wrote the arrangements for and leads the brass and string sections. (ABC South East NSW: Adriane Reardon)

"We went with a Mexican-inspired, mariachi arrangement for Creep", Nick Keeling said.

" The horn section brings a response to the melody, in a totally different genre to the song. But it fits together like a puzzle. "

Bumble Parsons picked up the baritone horn a few months ago after playing the tuba in an orchestra as a kid.

He plays in the Big Lost Band with his daughter Juniper, while the rest of the family sings in the choir.

Bumble Parsons and his daughter Juniper on baritone horn. (ABC South East NSW: Vanessa Milton)

He said it was a "special feeling" getting together to make music with friends and strangers.

"When the horns are blasting, it's good. It's good," Parsons said.

With each rehearsal, more and more earplugs fill more and more ears as the volume goes off the dial.

When the full band comes together, Nick Keeling said the usually "obnoxiously loud" horns are fighting to be heard over the electric guitars and basses.

"There's a reason rock bands don't have 30 guitars," he said.

"They might have three; three is a lot."

But he's ready to roll with it.

" Thirty guitars has to be better than three. It's 27 better. "

Forty guitar and bass players have joined this year's Big Lost Band. (ABC South East NSW: Adriane Reardon)

For Mr Keeling, the "barely controlled chaos" always seems to come together by show time.

And ultimately, it is all about the spectacle.

" You've seen choirs that are quite large, and marching bands that are gigantic. But where has anyone ever seen a rock band this big? "

As they prepare for their third Wanderer Festival, Ian Pidd said the band was "consolidating within the imagination of the community".

He is particularly pleased to see parents who brought their kids to play in the band at previous festivals are now picking up an instrument themselves.

"Once you make a sound together, it's very addictive," he said.

" It's a big, gorgeous, glorious musical thing. "

The Big Lost Band choir bring the full gamut of emotions to the set list. (ABC South East NSW: Adriane Reardon)

title: There's one thing that could sink WA Labor's racetrack, and its not angry residents
text:
WA's premier may be planning victory laps around his controversial election-promised Burswood Park racetrack, but his government is being coy about one crucial element that could sink the whole thing.

An element that could add to the project's $217 million price tag — and one that appears vital to its success.

The element in question? The land needed to build it.

And given the scrutiny it's under to keep the budget at bay, the government will be praying any potential deal to grab the land doesn't cost a penny.

A social media ad promoting the Burswood street circuit during the WA election campaign. (ABC News: Gian De Poloni)

The project — officially known as the Perth Entertainment and Sporting Precinct — and colloquially coined by the Opposition as "Rita's Racetrack" — has its fair share of critics.

Aside from noise worries from nearby apartment residents, the track has even split opinion within the Labor Party.

Sunbaking tourists will either love or loathe it, with the proposed track's southern leg doglegging some 50 metres from the edge of the Crown Towers swimming pool.

"You could be high-fiving Garth Tander from a sun-bed by the looks of things here," quipped Opposition Leader Basil Zempilas, one of the most vocal opponents of the project.

The racetrack butts up against the northern portion of the Crown Towers. (ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)

That led an unidentified state government spokesperson to have a swipe: "Basil Zempilas will say and do anything and stands for nothing."

"He is now arguing you can't have a vehicle within a kilometre of the Crown pool when we have hundreds of buses go past that very same pool every week."

Whether buses breach the peace as much as V8 Supercars is a question for the consultants.

But the much more existential problem? It's not the government's land to use in the first place.

How did we get here?

A large portion of vacant land closest to the casino — which used to be a golf course — was sold by former Premier Colin Barnett to Crown in 2013 so it could keep expanding its resort.

The land was valued at $95 million — but Mr Barnett sold it for $60 million.

There was a caveat though — Crown would have to build on it and open its new development by September 2028.

If not, the government was entitled to buy it back at the original purchase price.

But Crown has yet to progress any work on the vacant site, and in 2020 was looking to drop that caveat altogether and keep the land.

It is still unresolved to this day, despite the plan for the racetrack being far progressed.

The government appears to be banking on that 'use it or lose it' clause to be able to get what it wants — and needs.

Crown licence woes

In the meantime, Crown had problems of its own, ending with the publication of the Perth Casino Royal Commission in March 2022 which found it was unsuitable to hold a casino licence.

The next year, then-Environment Minister Reece Whitby signed an agreement allowing the state to take control of casino land bordering Perth Stadium that would also be needed for the racetrack precinct.

The site of proposed Perth's Burswood Park multi-use community hub and racetrack. (ABC News: Glyn Jones)

The rest is unclear.

How much, if anything, was paid? Had the government resolved to build the racetrack back then?

Mr Whitby was asked about that 2023 arrangement on Friday.

"Look, I don't know the details of that, it's not a portfolio responsibility of mine … it certainty wasn't at the time," Mr Whitby said on Friday.

WA government minister Reece Whitby. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"I'm not part of the current negotiations, I'll have to get back to you on that."

Land swap or sale?

Crown itself is on the record in support of the project.

Standing alongside the Racing and Gaming Minister in July welcoming the government's decision to allow Crown to keep its casino licence, then-Crown Resorts chair John Van Der Wielen said the racetrack was a "really exciting possibility".

"We're clearly supportive of any further developments on the peninsula," he said.

Crown Resorts chair John Van Der Wielen (right) was asked about the racetrack at a press conference in July. (ABC News: Nicolas Perpitch)

But what about the land issue? Would he consider a swap?

After all, the government controls several prized pieces of riverfront land adjacent to the Burswood site.

"I think it's too early days to speculate on anything like that but we're supportive of ongoing development," Mr Van Der Wielen said.

Treasurer Rita Saffioti is on the record saying the government is "very confident we will not be buying any land."

Political risk

It's risky for the government to be banking on acquiring land without paying anything for it, but politically it's even riskier.

It's got an Opposition ready to pounce on anything racetrack related using its "axe the track" slogan at any opportunity.

Basil Zempilas has become one of the most vocal opponents of the project. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

"For months now we've been asking in parliament will you need to acquire any land from Crown Casino to be able to complete this racetrack — acquire, purchase, land swap — we were told no by the state government," Opposition Leader Basil Zempilas said on Thursday.

"I'm not sure how that's going to be possible."

The Save Burswood Park Alliance rally on the steps of Parliament. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

It's understood despite the published maps of the racetrack, the designs are still being finalised, meaning it's still unclear just how essential this piece of land is.

If it is, the government will need to negotiate a deal — or worse, concede the project's cost will blow out, and it won't want to do that.

Loading...

title: Heads turn during Australia's first transcontinental quad tandem bike ride
text:
An eye-catching bright red bike with two wheels, four seats, eight pedals and 80 spokes is making its way across Australia.

Teachers Louise Ginn, Sonia Allum, Rachel Beaden and Anna Linbeck are covering more than 4,000 kilometres from Perth to Sydney, riding for suicide prevention charity Gotcha-4-Life.

Their choice of transportation, Ruby, is a rare sight in Australia, as only a few dozen of these specific quad tandem bikes have been released worldwide.

And its many notable features have so far left numerous bike mechanics scratching their heads.

The quad tandem bike is custom designed by a Canadian company. (Supplied: Ride4Life)

Specs and origin

Ruby was custom made by an Oregon-based company in the United States for a charity bike ride in Canada in 2023.

It was one of five quad tandem bikes used in a race from Keremeos to Nelson in British Columbia.

The bike was purchased second-hand earlier this year, and it took more than six months to get it from Vancouver to Australia.

The teachers are riding for a suicide prevention charity. (ABC News: Wade Stephens)

"It was quite the journey. Over 200 emails liaising with people around the world that were offering us quotes of how to get it here," Ms Linbeck said.

"The original quote was $35,000 to bring it here. But through connections, buying it second-hand … it was approximately $14,000 in the end."

The bike is 3.8 metres long, weighs 33 kilograms and has 22 gears, which are controlled by the rider in the rear seat.

Ruby also sports unique 40-spoke wheels to distribute the weight of the bike.

The quad tandem bike took six months to arrive from Canada. (ABC News: Wade Stephens)

Riding challenges

A bike as long and as heavy as Ruby comes with its challenges.

"For me at the front, the hardest part that I'm finding is definitely when turning corners. You can't turn corners very easily, there's a very wide turning circle," Ms Ginn said.

"And the side winds, they're the most challenging, just trying to keep the bike upright in those side winds.

"I've had my full body locked in to just keep the bike from being knocked over."

The team rode past the post office in Meckering, Western Australia. (Supplied: Ride4Life)

Customising the bike to suit each rider was also a time-consuming process.

"The handlebars are actually attached to the person in front of you," Ms Ginn said.

"A slight change in that then affects the rider in front with their seated position, so that's been a little bit of fun and games.

"It's one good reason why we don't change positions, because you'd be forever changing that.

"Once you find that sweet spot, you want to stick with it."

The quad tandem bike weighs almost 35 kilograms. (ABC News: Wade Stephens)

Maintenance challenges

During the lengthy journey, the chain of the bike has loosened, and some chain ring teeth have snapped off under the pressure of four people pedalling at once.

However, the back tyre has proved to be the biggest issue.

The quad tandem bike has caught the eye of many passersby. (ABC News: Wade Stephens)

"We've got on our third back wheel already," Ms Ginn said.

"We've had a lot of issues and sadly, we broke off one of the spokes from the base of the hub.

"We were unable to source a 40-spoke wheel, but we managed.

"The best case was a 36-spoke mountain bike wheel that was actually built for us in Adelaide."

Raising eyebrows

During the journey, the women have raised the eyebrows of not only onlookers, but bike shop mechanics who have been called upon to assist.

"First of all was Port Augusta, the bike mechanic there, you should have seen his raised eyebrows," Ms Ginn said.

"He was speechless … he could not fathom it. And he's like, 'I don't even think I'm going to be able to get it in my workshop. I'm going to have to put it in the backyard to work on it'.

The riders showed the quad tandem bike to students at Gol Gol Primary School. (ABC News: Wade Stephens)

"And then [in] Adelaide, once again, they all almost stopped their tools as the bike was walked through.

"They were just kind of blown away. And everyone that's quite bike mechanical, they're totally fascinated.

"They could spend days just looking and trying to comprehend how on Earth this thing actually works and was built.

"It takes a bit for them to get their head around."

title: Father's memory inspires Melbourne Storm star Cameron Munster to win
text:
Cameron Munster's late father always called his son before big games, encouraging him to back himself and not give away "stupid penalties".

The Melbourne Storm star stands just one game away from NRL grand final glory once again, but this time it will be different.

The Rockhampton and central Queensland product lost his father, Steven Munster, at age 58, during this year's State of Origin series, where he courageously led Queensland to a famous victory.

He hopes to do the same for the Melbourne Storm on Sunday night in the NRL grand final against the Brisbane Broncos in Sydney.

The late Steven Munster, wife, Debbie, and son Cameron after Melbourne's 2017 grand final win. (Supplied: Danielle Kersnovske)

And while his dad is no longer there to cheer for him, his proud mum, Debbie, and younger sister, Danielle Kersnovske, will be cheering him, along with adoring wife, Bianca, and their three children.

"We're just proud of him to achieve what he's done in his career, but especially this year, with what we've gone through," Ms Munster said.

"I'll be very nervous [in the crowd], but I'll sit there and continue to chew my nails that I don't have any of and I get myself into such a state it puts my blood pressure through the roof."

While Ms Munster will be in the 80,000-strong crowd cheering on her son, his sister will be nervously pacing around the lounge room of her home in Sarina in north Queensland.

"I hope we put 40 [points] on them," Ms Kersnovske joked.

"Dad will be whipping him home [up in heaven] if he makes a line break, I can tell you that and they'll probably be able to hear me cheering from Sydney."

A tearful Queensland coach Billy Slater hugs skipper Cameron Munster after this year's Origin decider. (Getty Images: Cameron Spencer)

Ms Kersnovske said the closely bonded Munster siblings missed their dad's phone calls before and after games.

"It was a tough one actually, last Friday night when they [Melbourne] got up over the Sharks," she said.

"You sit there waiting for him [dad] to call to boast about it, but he didn't."

She said their dad, a former champion sportsman in his own right and keen horse racing enthusiast, always had a few tips for her older brother.

"He'd be telling Cameron to back himself, hold the ball, do what he does best and for God's sake, tackle," Ms Kersnovske said.

"And no stupid penalties," Mrs Munster quickly chimed in.

The close-knit Munster family during happier times. (Supplied: Danielle Kersnovske)

Backyard footy dreams

Central Queensland is a renowned breeding ground for rugby league talent and on Sunday, six players from the area — Cameron Munster, Harry Grant, Jack Howarth (Melbourne Storms), and Ben Hunt, Kobe Hetherington and Tamika Upton (Brisbane Broncos) — will feature on grand final day.

The Munster siblings are naturally gifted in numerous sports and some of their fondest memories are playing footy in the backyard.

It is this carefree approach that Munster has adopted throughout his 235-game NRL career.

Cameron Munster wants to honour his late father, Steven, with a premiership trophy on Sunday night. (AAP: Joel Carrett)

"I know it sounds silly, but we all put this emphasis and pressure on the grand final, which it is, it's high stakes," he said.

" But the more you think about it during the week, the more you play the game in your head and you forget why you play the game. "

From causing chaos in the backyard to playing on the game's biggest stage, the Storm superstar has not forgetten his humble beginnings.

"I think sometimes we delve right into it and think, 'Oh, it's a pressure game'. Sometimes, I just feel like I'm playing in the backyard," he said.

Melbourne Storm players celebrate following their preliminary final win over Cronulla. (AAP: Joel Carrett)

As the Storm chase their first premiership since 2020 after losing last year's decider to Penrith, Munster said Melbourne were motivated not to go through the pain of defeat again.

"We've got to ice our moments, and that's what you play this game for, is to be in those big moments," he said.

"We always want to win grand finals. I think the boys had a little bit of a taste of how it was last year and what they felt and I'm sure a lot of the guys in the team that felt that feeling last year won't want to go through it again."

Cameron Munster passes the ball during last year's grand final against Penrith. (Getty Images: Cameron Spencer)

But mum, Debbie Munster, has hedged her bets on a good omen ahead of the decider.

"I do remember when Queensland won a State of Origin before Storm then won the grand final [in 2017 and 2020], so I'm hoping that'll be the case this year."

title: Kerr stuck on the bench again as Chelsea held by Manchester United
text:
Sam Kerr's carefully managed return to action has meant the Australia skipper has again been consigned to just a bit part for Chelsea as they lost their perfect Women's Super League record in a 1-1 draw at Manchester United.

Substitute Kerr was brought on in the 77th minute on Friday evening (local time), the fourth consecutive match she has come off the bench late since returning.

Though she only got a few touches during her 17 minutes, her busy presence helped give Chelsea some belated impetus in an even contest.

In total, Kerr has been on the pitch for 91 minutes in the four matches since her return, scoring just the one goal that she eked out in stoppage time of her first game back against Aston Villa.

Chelsea coach Sonia Bompastor was happy with her contribution, and that of her other substitutes brought on late as Chelsea tried urgently to mark the start of their title defence with a fifth straight win.

Instead, they had to settle for their first dropped points of the campaign, as they now lead the table on 13 points, ahead of United on 11.

"I wouldn't say it was satisfying, but it's a tough place to come," Bompastor said.

"We tried to find the winner in the last 30 minutes, and I think the players that came in did well, they brought energy and opportunities. But 1-1 was maybe a fair result."

United were thankful for a blistering goal from Anna Sandberg as they came from one down to earn their deserved point against the side that won the last six WSL titles.

Chelsea had gone ahead with a beautifully worked opener in the ninth minute when Catarina Macario's inspired back-heel set up Dutchwoman Wieke Kaptein to slot home into the corner.

Swedish defender Sandberg then equalised 11 minutes later, latching onto a ball from Ella Toone and hammering a thunderous first-time finish from outside the box past the world's top keeper, Hannah Hampton, her first goal for the club since signing 14 months ago.

AAP

title: The footy club with a $600,000 female change room but no women's team
text:
When local footy club, the Queanbeyan Blues, opened its new $600,000 dedicated female change room, there was a ribbon-cutting and a host of politicians present.

The government-funded project was designed to get more women and girls to participate in rugby league in the New South Wales town.

But just weeks earlier, the club's women's team had folded due to a player shortage.

At the town's rival club, the Queanbeyan Kangaroos, the women's side had suffered the same fate.

"I was actually pretty gutted," Roos player Chenice Jordan said.

"We really did want to play.

" Some of us did go to other clubs and some of us decided to not play or play union [instead] — it was really sad. "

Queanbeyan Kangaroos player Chenice Jordan. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

Roos player Kate Warren saw the writing on the wall, especially as the already small playing group was struck down by injury.

Despite that, the side's collapse just a few rounds into the competition was a "tough pill to swallow".

"Just like the boys, we're getting off work and we come here to be part of this culture and the club and put ourselves out there," Ms Warren said.

"For a lot of these women, they're mums … so it's an outlet, it's being part of something bigger than yourself."

At the men's first-grade level, the clubs thrived, with the two sides facing off in the grand final last month.

The number of females signing up to play the sport has increased by more than 17 per cent in the Canberra region. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

Record participation

Canberra Region Rugby League general manager Mark Vergano said while it was disappointing to see the demise of the two women's teams, the remaining clubs were "very strong".

Loading...

"Even though it was difficult from a competition perspective, we're still very confident about the growth arc that we've got in female participation," Mr Vergano said.

This year, more than 2,000 women and girls in the Canberra region signed up to play rugby league across all local clubs and age groups.

It is an annual increase of more than 17 per cent.

"Culturally, across the board, we want to make sure that rugby league is seen as a sport for all and it's an inclusive sport," Mr Vergano said.

"All our clubs, I think, embrace that. Some clubs are better at fostering that earlier than others."

Retaining female players beyond junior levels remains a challenge, as work, study, pregnancies and injuries get in the way.

'As important as the men'

Queanbeyan Blues representative Rebecca Maher said there needed to be a stronger focus on pathways for the region's strongest players.

"We do tend to lose a lot of them to [the NSWRL Women's Premiership] or the Queensland comp," Ms Maher said.

"If we could somehow make a viable pathway … giving those girls an option to be able to stay local, play for their junior clubs and then reach the ultimate goal [of the NRLW] if that's what they choose, would help to build our comp immensely."

Both Queanbeyan clubs are hopeful about reviving their women's teams next year.

It is hoped that more female players will take up the sport in the coming years. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

Kate Warren is optimistic about the future.

"Our junior club is working really hard to develop our under-17s girls, so hopefully in the next two years that's looking more positive," she said.

"With any kind of change in an institution, it's years before you see the effect of that."

Chenice Jordan is counting on it.

"Everyone makes it a big deal about the men's comp, but I feel like the women's comp is very much as important as the men's," she said.

title: Rodents, fire risks and overcrowding in seasonal worker housing: report
text:
Imagine moving across the world to work in a new country with no choice but to live in accommodation that is crammed, dangerous and plagued by mice.

That is the experience for many seasonal and migrant workers in regional Australia, according to a new report by the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute.

The study surveyed workers across Western Australia, Victoria and New South Wales and found low standards of housing across the three states.

'Bayview Heights' in Coral Bay houses seasonal workers. (Supplied: Tod Jones)

Managing director Michael Fotheringham said some workers were housed in "disused shearing sheds" that were crammed, lacked privacy and posed risks.

"There are safety and health implications for overcrowded accommodation for people working in quite labour-intensive ways," he said.

Worker dongas in Coral Bay, a popular tourist destination 11 hours north of Perth, had "intermittent mouse plagues" and were often "in extremely close confines, which pose a dangerous fire risk".

Sleeping quarters for workers from the Pacific Labour Migration scheme in NSW showing the absence of storage space. (Supplied: Denise Laverty.)

Conditions impact health

Mr Fotheringham said the "intrusive" conditions could affect workers' mental and physical health.

"[Being] crowded into that set-up is probably not the sort of standard that most Australians would want to be offering as a hospitality to people who are doing important roles as part of our economy," he said.

Dr Michael Fotheringham says overseas workers are vulnerable. (ABC News: Billy Cooper)

Mr Fotheringham said "precarious" visa requirements made it difficult for vulnerable seasonal workers to find better housing or raise concerns.

"If the accommodation that they're provided as part of their employment is not appropriate, safe or sufficient, their options are really only to either put up with it, or head back to their country of origin," he said.

"And for many, this is part of the economic sustainability of their families; they're sending money back to their families."

A Coral Bay employer says finding housing for workers is challenging. (Supplied: Tod Jones)

Mr Fotheringham said it was beholden on Australian employers to provide migrant and seasonal workers with safe and appropriate accommodation.

"It's not the way we should be representing ourselves to the world," he said.

Workers won't stay

The report references harrowing examples of migrant and seasonal worker housing in the idyllic coastal community of Coral Bay, 1,100km north of Perth.

One worker told researchers: "Most of these caravans and stuff, if there's a fire, [the residents] are not getting out".

Local business owner Mark Young knows the challenges of housing a seasonal workforce with limited options all too well.

He said his staff stayed in a variety of dwellings, from dongas, camper trailers, vans and community housing.

Mr Young said many moved on after a short period of time.

"The accommodation isn't enough for them to stay here for a long period of time," he said.

In the south of the state, Newton Orchard director Nicole Giblett has invested heavily in accommodation at her apple orchard in Manjimup, 300 kilometres south of Perth.

She employs more than 30 overseas workers who are housed on site.

Nicole Giblett says better accommodation for staff is worth the investment. (Supplied: Nicole Giblett)

"Accommodation is very difficult in this region ... [but] we're really happy with what we've been able to offer our guys because they deserve every bit of it, because they're amazing workers," she said.

What can be done?

Mr Fotheringham said a solution could be found in the conditions of working holiday visas and the Pacific Labour Mobility scheme.

"We need to think about the restrictions that are attached to visas for those workers that have employer-provided housing that tie them to that employer," he said

"If they're employed by an organisation and the housing that is provided is not appropriate, they have literally no choices to address that.

"We need to give people the opportunity to move around that."

title: A men's club so exclusive it almost blew up over the prospect of female guests
text:
The last time I had cause to write about the 131-year-old, men-only Melbourne establishment, the Savage Club, I was taking photos with my little Nokia of a comatose former ACTU official, Greg Sword, as he was being gingerly inserted into the back of an ambulance.

Sword had spent a very, very long Friday afternoon at the Savage Club, which sits like Gringotts on Bank Place, in the Harry Potter corner of the city. After many hours at the club, Sword and his lunch companion, former beer mogul and one-time Liberal prime ministerial hopeful, John Elliott, went on drinking at Syracuse, the bar across the road, but Elliott had volubly abandoned Sword, after he had locked himself in a women's toilet and could not be coaxed out by the staff.

Women now permitted in the bar at the Tasmanian Club — but they must be with a man Photo shows A sandstone building. The 163-year-old Tasmanian Club has, after much fuss, voted to overturn a rule excluding women from the bar — but before you ladies begin queuing up for a peek inside, please note — you'll still need to be accompanied by a gentleman.

I was there at the time, watching and recording all of it in my little notebook, as Elliott had moved unsteadily from table to table at which any attractive young woman was seated, until he finally gave up and Sword made his dash for the loos.

Asked by the hapless maître d' to please intervene, Elliott had barked, "He's not my problem!" and stomped out the door.

Although it's entirely possible that the man who hoped to Fosterise the world really yelled: "Pig's arse!"

In the end, an ambulance was called.

When I rang Sword the next day to inquire after his welfare, he told me he had been on medication which he had mixed with alcohol. He was mercifully feeling better.

It's a story that's followed me for years, and yet that incident has remained my sole peek inside the door of a club so exclusive that this week it almost blew up over the mere idea of letting a woman like me sit at a table for an Elliott/Sword-style long lunch. With presumably a lot less booze.

Can you spot the fallacy?

Barely three months into a six-month trial, the majority members of the exclusive Savage Club have voted to end immediately a proposal to allow women to lunch in the main dining room on Tuesdays and Wednesdays. Tuesdays and Wednesdays only.

Now, don't think for a second that this idea was a feminist takeover: in the grand tradition of Melbourne's men's clubs — all founded when the city was drowning in gold — I am happy to report that steely, capitalist principles alone informed the idea of the trial: the Savage Club needed the money.

Karens 'badly done by' Photo shows A composite image of three women recorded on video which has been posted on social media. One of Australia's top linguistics experts believes the pop culture term has evolved into one with derogatory and offensive connotations.

The then club president had bemoaned to members that lunch attendances were falling, as business groups and members wanting to dine with their wives had to seek alternative city restaurants. A club info sheet sniffed that the places these members and their presumably inconveniently gendered partners had been chased to were "probably nowhere near as good as the Savage Club", so something had to be done to get them back (someone send that guy a Melbourne Good Food Guide, stat).

So, a trial commenced, on those days only.

It did not go well.

A faction of men angry at the invasion called for an extraordinary meeting in an email that was just as extraordinary. For the kids playing along at home, see if you can spot the fallacy:

"The loud and boisterous bohemian behaviour that the club is famous for will now have to be tempered for fear of upsetting a 'Karen' at the other end of the dining room. "Our wives no longer will have the comfort of knowing we are at a male-only venue, so long hours spent at the club will no longer be viewed as favourable on the home front."

Can you see it? On the one hand, men will become neutered and constrained by the mere presence of women but, at the same time, they might become wild and be plausibly accused by their wives of poor behaviour if said women were there at all.

Such alluring women would, of course, only be there in the company of their male partners and therefore preoccupied with their own marriage, but let's put that to one side.

These clubs are the weirdest anomaly

Women in the dining room — or "ducks on the pond", as the immoveable Australian tradition would have it — had become intolerable. And here the trial ends.

One assumes the Savage Club will now have to hire Melbourne luminary chef, Andrew McConnell, to keep the wandering palates of male members (and their wives) firmly at Bank Place.

For the women who were part of the trial, never has the Groucho Marx dictate been more meaningful: writer Jen Vuk was one of them. If they wanted to have her as a member, she didn't want to join. Writing in The Age, Vuk believed she'd dodged a bullet — or a chewy braised kidney: "You can keep the nostalgia, exclusivity, taxidermy and misogyny," she sniffed.

These clubs, which still exist right around the country, are the weirdest anomaly. They sit jostled up against the Australia they firmly shut their doors against: the ramen bars and hookah joints and dumpling cafes and nightclubs and restaurants and shops owned and run by the generations of migrated Australians not represented in their membership. The clubs' purpose in a modern Australia seems almost neurotic.

Sign up for Weekend Reads in your inbox Photo shows Virginia Trioli in a stylish suit on a set with lighting behind her Start your weekend with the best of the ABC's journalism, presented by Virginia Trioli. Discover compelling features, big ideas and revealing analysis to understand the stories that matter to Australians.

I've only set foot in one of them, I think. I can't remember who invited me to lunch, but I vividly recall weak sunlight filtering through heavy Victorian windows that didn't seem to have been cracked open since Edward the Seventh was tupping Lily Langtree. Old men were nodding off over their cauliflower soup, and I could smell the dust. I perched on the edge of my chair with buttocks clenched: there wasn't a surface I wanted to touch.

I was part of an original group of Melburnians who were invited by Myer scion and arts patron, Carillo Gantner, to be foundation members of a rival club to the untouchable establishment, but I couldn't muster the enthusiasm.

And the former state shadow treasurer, Louise Staley, once spotted me lurking in the foyer of the Lyceum Club, waiting for the architect, Kerstin Thompson, who had completed a beautiful redevelopment of the 113-year-old women-only club. She asked if I wanted to become a member: it was useful to have a place in town you could sit and make some calls, ease off your shoes and pull out your laptop, she said.

The Lyceum was founded next door to the Melbourne Club as a place for the excluded wives to go while the members were at lunch. Standing in the club's lovely tree-top level lounge, you look down over the grand rear garden of the Melbourne Club — a clever way to keep an eye on the goings-on back there. No thank you, I said. Groucho knows why.

This weekend, my admirable colleagues are the greatest defenders of our great democracy, at a time when this institution has never seemed more fragile. Here is the brilliant Julia Baird introducing you to this year's Boyer Lectures, which focuses on Australia's "future in a changing world"; and the wonderful Annabel Crabb has taken over the national sausage sizzle with her new social history program, Annabel Crabb's Civic Duty — everything you always needed to know about our political process.

Have a safe and happy weekend. This is the vibe those of us fleeing our desk jobs need this weekend, courtesy of the power and beauty of Sydney singer-songwriter Madeleine Powers and Rageflower. Go well.

Virginia Trioli is presenter of Creative Types and a former co-host of ABC News Breakfast and Mornings on ABC Radio Melbourne.

title: Taylor Swift's new album isn't the only one you should hear this weekend
text:
Yes, we know — Taylor Swift just dropped a new album.

But in the weeks before The Life of a Showgirl took over the conversation, some of the best records of 2025 arrived far more quietly, and they deserve your attention.

If you're all-in on Taylor right now, no judgement. But if there's room in your rotation for more than one artist, we've got a handful of incredible albums you might've missed — and they're absolutely worth discovering.

Olivia Dean — The Art of Loving

Already a hit with young audiences at Laneway Festival, Olivia Dean headlines venues on Australia's east coast next month. (Supplied: Universal Music Australia)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

The UK artist's self-assured second album fulfils what her 2023 debut album Messy promised: Olivia Dean is something special.

The Art of Loving has all the hooky pleasures of commercial pop but few of the cliches, couching the 26-year-old's effortlessly airy, understated voice in classy arrangements and songwriting with a vintage flair.

Cuts like Nice To Each Other and Man I Need are instant earworms whose meaningful sentiments makes them even more addictive. Namely, overcoming relationship angst with pleas toward tenderness, honesty, and self-worth.

"I can't tell if you need me or want me all that much" Dean frets between vintage horns on Close Up, then takes pride in letting go on the soulful ballad Let Alone The One You Love.

The string-laden Loud sounds genuinely crestfallen, but then the flirty So Easy (To Fall In Love) glides over a Burt Bacharach trumpet, shimmying guitar and luxurious piano as Dean proclaims to be the "perfect mix of Saturday night and the rest of your life".

No song overstays its welcome, and despite their breezy execution, each makes a memorable impression with charming performances and convincing emotional stakes.

For fans of: RAYE, Norah Jones, Jorja Smith

Al Newstead

Wednesday — Bleeds

North Carolina indie rock band Wednesday soar to new heights on their sixth album. (Supplied: Dead Oceans)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

On their sixth album Bleeds, Wednesday sharpen the edges of their chaotic creative impulses, offering a thrilling blend of scorched noise and dusty twang that feels occasionally volatile and often comforting.

It's a step forward from their 2023 breakthrough Rat Saw God, dialling down the abrasiveness just enough to let their songwriting shine through.

The guitars are a patchwork of textures — twangy, searing, sometimes sweet — jammy without indulgence, familiar without falling into imitation.

But Karly Hartzman is Bleeds's emotional core. Her voice is impassioned and unpretentious, her lyrics full of strange, vivid snapshots of everyday horror and humour.

On Phish Pepsi, she sings: "We watched a Phish concert and Human Centipede, two things I now wish I had never seen", a simple line illustrative of her funny, bleak, relatable worldview.

Six albums deep, Wednesday are making the best music of their career — and they're still in their 20s. Bleeds is proof that their creative fire is only getting brighter.

For fans of: Pavement, MJ Lenderman, Veruca Salt

Dan Condon

Mel Blue — nomorejacketsplease

Mel Blue began life as a six-piece, then reduced to a duo, and now consists of Oscar Sharah, Luke Gerber and Jacob Siles. (Supplied: Nettwerk Music Group)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

Sydney trio Mel Blue thought relocating to London would skyrocket their career. The reality was different.

Instead of gigging across Europe and DJing iconic British clubs until the early hours, they got day jobs as teachers while struggling with the isolation of adapting to a new lifestyle. But their personal loss became their music's gain.

Absorbing the vibrant sounds of London's underground dance music, nomorejacketspleaserattles with lively jungle breaks and garage beats. From the soulful samples bouncing through $ame Thing to the '90s club energy of Diamonds, these songs excel at putting fresh spins on nostalgic sounds.

The candy-coated Secret Crush sounds like an undiscovered R&B bop in fast forward. Addictive standout None Of That tweaks the vocals of collaborator Sycco over lush drum'n'bass and wonky synths.

Mel Blue also skilfully merge animated tempos with contemplative songwriting and autumnal atmosphere.

A pitch-shifted vocal laments broken trust and heartache over a shuffling pulse and warm synths on the tender Be That To You, while Same As I thrives in misty melancholy.

The wide-ranging styles and textures hang together as a subtle narrative encompassing friendship, growth, and reinvention. "A rumination on finding hope through distance and change," as the band put it.

If Britain doesn't start paying attention to Mel Blue, then Australia absolutely should.

For fans of: Mall Grab, Fred Again.., Piri & Tommy

Al Newstead

Ayesha Madon — The Unanticipated Prequel

The Unanticipated Prequel is the debut EP from Ayesha Madon, who many will recognise from Netflix series Heartbreak High. (Supplied: Future Classic)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

The idea that Australia's recent chart struggles come down to a lack of talent just doesn't stack up.

On her debut EP, Sydney's Ayesha Madon serves up six tracks of world-class, effervescent pop — songs that should already be stuck in every Australian's head.

The sleek and bubbly sound of Eulogy is at odds with its dark lyric, as Madon outlines the flaws people might bring up at her funeral, and brushes off the good things they might say as lies.

Blame Me dives into the ache of unrequited love, pairing frustration and vulnerability with sleek production from the ever-reliable Japanese Wallpaper.

The EP's two new tracks — bubbly raver Supervision and the bizarre-yet-sassy Jonestown — stand tall alongside the earlier singles, showing the breadth of Madon's stylistic range while retaining a consistent voice that helps these six songs make sense together.

These songs prove Madon can hold her own alongside the best pop artists in the world. So, what's it going to take for the mainstream gatekeepers to get behind her?

For fans of: Sabrina Carpenter, Remi Wolf, BENEE

Dan Condon

Geese — Getting Killed

Getting Killed follows 2023 cult hit 3D Country, and frontman Cameron Winter's raved-about debut solo album Heavy Metal. (Supplied: Partisan Records)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

When an album begins with the alarming refrain of "THERE'S A BOMB IN MY CAR!" against a shambolic groove and muddied trumpet, you know you're dealing with something radical.

Don't let the cacophony deter you, the fourth album from Geese is the thrilling sound of rock music being deconstructed and reassembled into fascinating new possibilities.

Reinvention is central to these four New York City 20-somethings, who've been playing, writing and absorbing the guitar-band canon since before they could legally drink.

Getting Killed was recorded with Kenneth Blume (formerly known as hip hop producer Kenny Beats) in 10 days.

That spontaneity supercharges a record that tramples all over its varied inspirations — everything from Rolling Stones, Television and Velvet Underground to Van Morrison — to forge strange, intoxicating songs.

Rubbery rhythms meet a sampled Ukranian choir on the title track; Cobra and Au Pays du Cocaine rewire their idiosyncrasies into swooning, sentimental moments.

The craggy grooves of Bow Down and 100 Horses buttress frontman Cameron Winter's mercurial melodies, while his shamanic presence powers the deceptively cathartic Taxes and epic closer Long Island City Here I Come.

"You were there the day the music died," Winter hollers as the latter unravels. "And I'll be there the day it dies again."

In an era ruled by algorithmic trends and AI slop, it's invigorating to hear a group that refuses to rely on the formulaic. Geese sideline convention for creative freedom on an album unlike any you'll hear this year.

For fans of: Television, Car Seat Headrest, Black Country, New Road

Al Newstead

Nine Inch Nails — TRON: Ares

TRON: Ares features collaborations with Scottish producer Hudson Mohawke and Boyz Noise. (Supplied: Universal Music Australia)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

In the past decade, Trent Reznor is typically busier with his award-hoovering film score work alongside Atticus Ross than with Nine Inch Nails — the influential industrial rock group he founded in the late 80s.

It's a welcome surprise then, that the score to Disney's Tron "threequel" doubles as NIN's first album in half a decade, and the star attraction is four Reznor-fronted songs.

As Alive As You Need To Be and Shadow Over Me operate in his familiar wheelhouse of digital dystopia, but whose vocoders and vintage synths nod to Daft Punk's Tron: Legacy (the best thing about that 2010 film) and original Tron composer Wendy Carlos.

Then there's the brooding trip hop of I Know You Can Feel It, and the uncharacteristically sensitive Who Wants To Live Forever? where twinkling keys meet the tender vocals of Spanish singer Judeline.

The remaining instrumentals steep Reznor and Ross's reliable soundtrack signatures — frosty piano, elegant atmospherics, scorched-earth intensity — in analogue throbs, drones and buzzes befitting of a sleek, neon-lit sci-fi universe.

It isn't groundbreaking but TRON: Ares is dependable proof Reznor and Ross haven't run out of ways to sound majestically menacing.

For fans of: HEALTH, Drab Majesty, Perturbator

Al Newstead

Big Thief — Double Infinity

The widely lauded Big Thief contended with a personnel change in the lead up to their sixth album Double Infinity. (Supplied: 4AD/Remote Control)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

Some records you feel in your bones. There's a looseness and warmth to Big Thief's sixth album, born from the band's decision to record with a community of friends and collaborators. While the songs are great, the vibes are even better.

It hasn't been an easy road. The loss of bassist Max Oleartchik marked a major shift for the New York group, and the weight of expectation after a decade of critical acclaim must have loomed large.

Yet rather than retreat, Big Thief have leaned into change, and emerged with a record that feels freer, more open, and, at times, quietly joyful.

Adrianne Lenker's songwriting remains the emotional core. Her reflections on love, life, and the strange beauty of existence are often delivered with a gentle touch here.

There's less devastation, more light, and it never feels forced. Lenker's joy is subtle, grounded, and deeply human.

From the chatter and chuckles that usher in album highlight Los Angeles to the communal harmonies that ripple through the album, Double Infinity radiates a subtle but infectious communal joy.

The emotional weight is still there, it just won't leave you quite as devastated as some of the band's best work.

It's too soon to say where this sits in Big Thief's remarkable catalogue — their albums always take time to fully reveal themselves.

But one thing's clear: Double Infinity reaffirms their place among the most vital and visionary bands of our time.

For fans of: boygenius, Faye Webster, John Prine

Dan Condon

Parcels — LOVED

A true globetrotting act, Parcels recorded their new album in studios across Berlin, Byron Bay, Sydney, and Mexico. (Supplied: Because Music)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

If you've been hankering for a follow-up to Daft Punk's Random Access Memories, you clearly haven't discovered Parcels.

The Australian quintet has been pulling at the same sonic threads — chic disco-pop, pristine jazz-funk, and soulful soft rock — since forming in 2014.

Their throwback sound (and wardrobe) even caught the attention of Daft Punk, who produced their breakout 2017 single Overnight.

They're now on their third album, and after the sprawling double album Day/Night, LOVED goes back to basics.

It wastes no time rolling out feel-good funk on tunes like Tobeloved, Yougotmefeeling and Leaveyourlove (the title stylisation is a hangover from when Parcels recorded songs onto a computer with a broken spacebar).

Leaves is another example of the ensemble's flawless multi-part vocal harmonies and airtight grooves that exhibit both instrumental mastery and contagious immediacy.

The shiny surfaces might be too polished for some, and the lyrical fixation on love occasionally knocks on the door of cliché, but Parcels aren't a glorified wedding band.

Ifyoucall and Summerinlove grapple with the break-up blues, while the slowed-down, loose indie rock of Safeandsound conveys comfort in uncertainty.

LOVED isn't a huge creative leap forward but for Parcels novices, it's the perfect introduction.

For fans of: Jungle, L'Impératrice, LEISURE

Al Newstead

Acopia — Blush Response

Blush Response is the dreamy and nostalgic new album from Melbourne trio Acopia. (Supplied: Scenic Route)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

If you know you know. Melbourne's Acopia have quietly carved out a space in the global underground in recent years, blending the familiar sounds and textures of dreamy pop and moody trip hop to create something truly their own.

On Blush Response, their third album, they reach a new creative peak.

You may find yourself feeling nostalgic while listening, as the group weave these familiar shades into beautiful, hazy, understated pop songs.

Kate Durman's soft, expressive, magnetic voice is the album's anchor.

Her melodies glide through a collage of breakbeats, synths, and guitar lines, delivering hooks that feel both effortless and deeply felt.

At their core, these are deceptively simple pop songs — but each one is rich with emotional nuance and sonic detail.

Blush Response doesn't reinvent the genre, but it doesn't need to. Acopia know exactly what they're doing, and they do it with rare precision.

For fans of: The Cure, Slowdive, Massive Attack

Dan Condon

Cut Copy — Moments

Cut Copy’s sophisticated synth-pop was always more intimate than 2000s contemporaries like The Presets and Midnight Juggernauts. (Supplied: Cutters Records)

Spotify | YouTube | Apple Music

Pioneers of Australia's mid-to-late 2000s indie-electro wave, Cut Copy's seventh album laces their formative synth-driven sound with a significantly mellower sense of artisanal atmosphere.
